The Chief Local Representative Dear Sir, The Bahrain Government has contracted with Messrs. Holloway Brothers for the installation of a town water supply in Manama. The system of distribution will be through a ring-main round Manama feeding a sub-main with extensions to consumers and public wasAhouses and supply hydrants for the public. The pumping plant, consisting of three sets o' maps and storage tanks will be loc ted in the M cipal Garden. It is proposed that water should be supplied from two new artesian wells in the garden as shown on the attached plan. We have not the necessary equipment and material for drilling and casing two wells, the contractors only undertake the provision and erection of pumps, machinery, water tower and lay out of mains and sub-mains; not the drilling of the wells. Would your company be prepared to sink two wells and provide casing, isolating valves etc., for the Government of Bahrain in the Municipal Garden? Your assistance in this matter would be greatly appreciated in furthering a public utility scheme for the benefit of the inhabitants of Manama. If you can assist would you kindly let me know when you could commence operations? The site Is clear and has been seen by Group Captain Leigh and Mr. Godfrey. The Bahrain Government has placed orders in the United Kingdom for the supply and installation of a town water scheme for the supply of water through mains and auxiliary feeders to all residential areas in the town* The scheme includes water supply points distributed throughout the town where water can be drawn free of charge by the public, also wash places and Dhobi Ghats. Occupants of houses who desire a private water supply inside their premises will be required to pay for the water which they consume. The water consumption will be recorded by a meter installed on the premises of each consumer. The tariff per gallon will be announced at a later date. Water pressure available will be sufficient to provide a water supply to a height of at leart 50 feet. The Government of Bahrain will only instal the water connection up to the consumer^ meter, all interval services from the meter, must be carried out by the owner of the premises, but before water service is connected the interior installation must be approved by the State Engineer. In order to decide approximcT^tely how many meters will be required householders are requested to inform the State Engineer in writing the number of service points which they will need, i.e. the number of supply taps on the premises. The anticipated date for the completion of thewater supply scheme is March, 1948, but as sections of the mains are laid, water from them will be available for the residents in those areas. Sd. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the back cover with 28; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 1-17; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. Pagination: the file notes at the back of the file (ff 25-27) have been paginated using pencil.

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence regarding the installation of a water supply in Manama (for which Messrs. Holloway Brothers Limited received the contract). Much of this correspondence is between Charles Belgrave, Adviser to the Government of Bahrain, and the Political Agency in Bahrain.A copy of a Government of Bahrain public notice regarding the installation of the water supply is contained on folio 13.The file also contains letters from R M Brown, the Chief Local Representative of the Bahrain Petroleum Company (BAPCO), as the company was commissioned to conduct the analysis of the water supplied by the new water scheme.
